brief hospital course:
ms. [**known lastname **] was evaluated in the ed and thought to have
pulmonary edema. due to her high oxygen requirement and clinical
picture, she was given iv [**known lastname 11573**] with minimal response. she was
admitted to the sicu where [**known lastname 11573**] [**known lastname **] was initiated. below is
her hospital course by system:

1. neurologic: mental status improved by hospital day 2.
confusion was felt to be secondary to hypoxia and uti. psych
meds were continued. she was noted to have tremor and weakness
on her right side. neurology was consulted and made
recommendations for  eeg to r/o seizures, head ct to eval
evolution of stroke. keppra was continued at current dose. head
ct without contrast on [**4-22**] demonstrated unchanged left frontal
parafalcine dural calcification. no mass effect, bleed or
midline shift. mild atrophy was noted. cpap was recommended to
decrease change of hypoxia that could increase seizure
potential. this was set up, but she refused to wear due to
claustraphobia sensation.

2. pulmonary: pulmonary edema responded to diuresis. chest ct
was done on [**4-17**] demonstrating pulmonary edema with possible
bilateral pneumonia. cardiology consult was obtained and it was
deemed that she had chf secondary to worsening mr. [**first name (titles) 11573**] [**last name (titles) **]
and metolazone were given. she was also treated with a
7-day-course of vancomycin for pna.

3. cardiac: due to her history of diastolic chf and a bnp of
~10,000 at admission, patient was thought to be in chf which
exacerbated her [**last name (un) **]. tte on [**2155-4-17**] showed normal lvef with
worsening mr compared to previous tte on 2/[**2155**]. cardiology
agreed with the plan. recommendations were to continue to
diurese then re-echo to evaluate mr and as once euvolemic.

4. gi: dobbhoff tube was clogged on admission and was exchanged
on hd#1. tf was restarted to 40 ml/hr of norvasource with
beniprotein 21g/day. she developed diarrhea likely r/t tube
feeds. stool was negative for c.diff on [**4-24**] and [**4-26**].
colchicine which was started [**4-21**] was likely causing diarrhea.
on hd 10 the patient passed multiple clots per rectum and had a
hct drop. she was transferred to the icu and was transfused 6

colonoscopy done on [**4-26**] was significant for friability and

feedings were stopped allowing for bowel rest. on [**4-29**],

5. gu: diuresed with furosemide, metolazone and chlorothiazide.

6. hem/id: on admit wbc was 35k with fever of 102.4. she was

lower gi bleed and stabalized after multiple transfussions.
cipro and flagyl were started and should complete a 14 day

7. musculoskeletal: she complained of increased discomfort in

ct chest/abdomen/pelvis ([**4-25**]):
1. multiloculated simple-appearing left pleural effusion with
adjacent regions of lung collapse as described above. underlying
infection within these regions of collapse as well as empyema
cannot be excluded on this non-contrast examination.
additionally mild-to-moderate centrilobular emphysema with
probable underlying tracheal and proximal bronchial malacia.
2. calcified and non-calcified pleural plaques consistent with
underlying asbestos exposure. no parenchymal findings to suggest
underlying asbestosis. given the involvement of the medial
pleural surface on the left as well as some regions of
underlying nodularity, a dedicated biopsy and/or vats
examination would be of benefit to exclude underlying
mesothelioma if a contrast enhanced exam can not be performed.
3. extensive atherosclerotic calcification with 2.6cm of focal
region of ulceration involving the inferior aspect of the aortic
arch.

infectious or inflammatory with ischemia felt less likely.
5. known underlying sequelae of cirrhosis with mild-to-moderate
intra-abdominal ascites.
6. large fecal load noted within the right and transverse colon.
fecalized matter within the stomach may suggest underlying
gastroparesis and/or severe ileus.
7. fluid-filled distended esophagus also likely related to
underlying dysmotility. can consider further evaluation with
dedicated esophogram when clinically feasible.
8. cholelithiasis without evidence of acute cholecystitis.
9. large sacral decubitus ulcer with extension to involve the
inferior sacrum and coccyx which display demineralization and

brief hospital course:
# septic arthritis
he had an mrsa infection of the left knee prosthetic joint, s/p
washout on [**2105-4-23**]. gram stain was negative for organisms and
showed many pmns. id was following and recommended for a 6-week
course of daptomycin (dosed after hd) and rifampin (last dose on
[**2105-6-3**]) and will likely require long-term suppresion after if
prosthesis not removed. if pt has prosthesis removed, he will no
longer require rifampin; please be aware of med interaction when
starting and stopping rifampin. he should be followed by the
infectious disease specialist at [**hospital1 **] (our id fellow will
contact with more info), and he will need weekly monitoring of
ck (daptomycin) and cbc, ast, alt, and ck (rifampin). morphine
was used for post-operative pain and pain related to infection.
he should continue physical therapy.

# hospital acquired pneumonia and respiratory status
his sputum grew out gram negative rods and he completed an 8-day
course of ceftazidime and tobramycin with the last dose given on
[**2105-5-4**]. during the course of the admission, possibly in part due
to morphine given for knee pain, he was noted to be somnulent
with abgs indicative of hypercarbia. cxr showed white out of the
left lung on two separate occasions, presumably due to mucuous
plugging because follow-up cxrs improved after chest pt and
positive pressure ventilation. a ct chest was done during the
admission. this showed multiloculated simple-appearing left
pleural effusion with adjacent regions of lung collapse (see
full report above). this should be followed up in a 3 months
with repeat ct to assess for improvement in the effusion after
his pneumonia is treated.  he required intermittent ventilator
support at baseline at night.

# end-stage renal disease on hemodialyisis
he was continued on m-w-f hemodialysis schedule.

# hypotension
he required dopamine drip transiently. [**last name (un) **] stim test was
normal. we were unsure of the cause for his hypotension, but
felt that it may be due to sepsis from knee infection versus
fluid removal from hemodialysis. dopamine drip was turned off
several days prior to discharge. pt able to tolerate low dose
metoprolol at time of discharge for rate control.

# history of gastrointestinal bleeding
we held anticoagulation and continued his home proton-pump
inhibitor.

# sacral decrubitus ulcer
he underwent ct torso that showed sacral osteomyelitis. wound
care service was following and recommended for v.a.c. therapy
dressing changed monday and thursday @ 125 mmhg in addition to
the following: pressure relief per pressure ulcer guidelines,
turn and reposition every 1-2 hours, heels off bed surface at
all times, waffle boots bilaterally, elevate legs while sitting,
moisturize bilateral legs and feet twice daily, commerical wound
cleanser or normal saline to irrigate/cleanse open wound, pat
the tissue dry with dry gauze, apply protective barrier wipe to
peri-wound tissue and air dry, cover with soft sorb dressing,
secure with medipore tape, change dressing daily.

# coronary artery disease
there was no evidence of ischemia during this admission with an
unremarkable ecg and no complaints of chest pain, ck normal. his
troponin was elevated most likely due to end-stage renal
disease. we continued his home aspirin. a tte showed severe tr
with a dilated and hypokinetic right ventricle.

# history of seizure disorder
we continued his home keppra at a dose adjusted for end-stage
renal disease.

# constipation
there was increasing abdominal distention noted on exam and a ct
torso showed impacted stool so he was given a saline enema
through his ostomy with a resultant large amount of stool
output. of note, he was receiving saline enema through ostomy q3
days at rehab with good results. he was continued on docusate,
lactulose, and senna.

# atrial fibrillation
this is chronic, and he is not on anticoagulation due to history
of gastrointestinal bleed. he was initially tachycardic to the
low 100s; this improved with iv hydration. beta-blocker was
added for rate control.

# access
a picc line has been placed for antibiotics, in addition to
which he has a tunneled right subclavian for hd.

# code status
his code status is full code, with family agreeing to only one
shock in the event of cardiac arrest.
